@shad0wbits It's a fair question - I haven't seen enough info about the likely leakers here to make an assessment. There is precedent for leaked data to be altered though...I thought I recalled a good roll-up of that somewhere, but can't find it. Maybe someone knows what I'm thinking of?
@uuallan https://t.co/cxanMNt81i

I know I'm a Debbie Downer. I fully support any joy or glee you get from reading the leaks, and I'm right there with you. Just...don't make any big decisions based solely on leaked info, okay? https://t.co/xXwMWR7N54

Yes, the Conti leaks are interesting and analysts should look at them. But remember we don't know if the info was altered before leaking or if it's completely accurate. Intel analysts consider multiple sources before reaching an assessment. I highly recommend that approach.

@tcr00x Follow @JohnHultquist, @RALee85, and @DAlperovitch. There are probably others but those are the ones I can think of off the top of my head at 7:30 pm on a Friday :)

@Ledtech3 @ffforward I don't think any are public, but honestly I haven't had time to look. I bet if you search on the format `123 (1).zip/123.xlsb` they'll be on sandboxes somewhere, seems like this was pretty widespread.

5. Think of the people on the ground in Ukraine and send whatever types of good thoughts you believe in. This is a real conflict with real human consequences, and we as cybersecurity professionals shouldn't forget that.
4. Take @RobertMLee's advice and take the weekend off if you aren't responding to anything urgent. https://t.co/KTAuC032EY

3. Have someone from your team keep an eye on OSINT and stay in comms with community colleagues. If there's cyber activity, especially that expands beyond Ukraine, someone is likely going to share it. The entire community is hyper-analyzing EVERYTHING right now.
2. Look at sources with helpful, actionable guidance like this @Mandiant guide: https://t.co/kaZjhMjTnn and decide if you need to update your IR plans.

If it's not actionable, it's not intelligence. Yes, we should watch what's happening in Ukraine and orgs should prepare appropriately. However, vague warnings like "prepare for cyber attack!" aren't helpful. Here's what I recommend doing: 1. Go find your incident response plans.

Good thread. I'll add that we should all be cognizant of cognitive biases right now... Confirmation bias: many are looking for ANYTHING to fit the hypothesis that Russian cyber attacks are happening. Anchoring: Focusing too much on one piece of info, often the first piece we see. https://t.co/y57xmKU78k
